ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I definitely felt like my Chinese has improved significantly after taking this course

I improved my speaking by practicing Chinese everyday. I improved my character writing by having homework everyday which included writing, and I improved my knowledge of different grammatical and sentence structures.
I learned how to write, speak, and read chinese much better than before, especially with my heritage background.
I greatly improved my ability to read and write Chinese, including words and phrases that are very useful when referring to everyday objects, life, and activities.
I strengthened my oral, reading, and handwriting skills in Mandarin greatly through this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:  really puts in an effort to make class a fun and engaging place to learn Chinese. There are a lot of opportunities to practice your oral skills and the quizzes / tests are really helpful for learning new vocabulary.

Weaknesses: None that I can think of

I think having class everyday is both a strength and a weakness of the course because it helps you practice the language often and improves your memory, but it also is a large time commitment because you need to take time every day to do the homework, and there are multiple quizzes to study for every week. I think the course could be improved by moving the asynchronous day to friday

Love the asynchronous day, super helpful to study for the friday exams and also good to do small projects, review material, or other assignments without having to come in that day for another class. Would love to have another asynchronous day for the course. Strengths is good organization, bad is lots of work, but that is how you practice.

As a language course, it was incredibly heavy on speaking and writing. I think that with the weekly quizzes, we were given ample opportunity to practice writing words. In addition, the lesson readings were very real-life-centric, so the phrases we learned to read and write were quite useful. I think that the homework is where most of the learning and improvement occurred, as they were repetitive (in style) but useful exercises. Perhaps one improvement is that we could be given more opportunities to practice speaking.
I thought that the entire course was very well structured, and I cannot pinpoint many weaknesses in this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if you speak Chinese at home with your family or gone to Chinese school in the past.

If you are a heritage speaker, I would recommend this class because it focuses much more on speaking, reading, and writing than listening comprehension, which is much more effective for heritage student.
yes, it was a very good course for heritage chinese speakers
If you are a heritage Chinese learner and placed into L3, definitely take this class. It will do a lot of good for your Chinese writing and reading.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to any student looking to strengthen their Mandarin.
